com.karacasoft.cardboardui.view

Class AdapterView3D

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.karacasoft.cardboardui.view.View3D
      • com.karacasoft.cardboardui.view.AdapterView3D
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GridView3D

    public class AdapterView3D
extends View3D
    Very simple AdapterView implementation.

    Can be used to display lists. An implementation of BaseAdapter3D is required.

    List display size can be increased/decreased by using setMaxItemsShown(int).

    Here's a simple AdapterView3D usage:

    adView = new AdapterView3D(this);

    //centralizing the view
    adView.translate(-2.0f, -4.0f, 0.0f);
    adView.setWidth(4.0f);

    //This is a subclass of BaseAdapter3D. See BaseAdapter3D documentation.
    final ListAdapter adapter = new ListAdapter(this);
    adapter.setItems(items);

    adView.setAdapter(adapter);
     Created by Karaca on 5/28/2015.
    See Also:
    BaseAdapter3D

      • draw

        public void draw(com.google.vrtoolkit.cardboard.Eye eye)
        Description copied from class: View3D
        Draws the View on GLES context. Called once for each eye. Draw method, sends the view data to OpenGL program every frame. Theoretically, there will be significant performance issues if the user tries to draw too many objects on the screen. It can be solved by using the graphics memory to hold view data. But drawing different objects will still impact the performance. So the best solution is simply avoiding drawing a lot of objects on screen. I never tested for the limits though. The View should be initialized first. Or it will print a warning level log message that says "View draw skipped. (View not ready)"
        Overrides:
        draw in class View3D
        Parameters:
        eye - is given by the CardboardActivity context.

      • update

        public void update()
        Description copied from class: View3D
        Updates the View. Checks if the user is looking at the view. Handles Focus Mode. Performs the trigger if the Cardboard trigger was used. It should be extended on every View3D subclass to handle changes on the particular View.
        Overrides:
        update in class View3D

      • measure

        public void measure()
        Description copied from class: View3D
        A view's width, height and depth, depends on the View itself. So every specialized view subclass should implement its own measure method to calculate its width, height and depth. It is possible to leave these fields empty. But for convenience, subclasses should implement a measure method for each View.
        Specified by:
        measure in class View3D
